com.thesonofthom.tools

Class TimeFormatter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.thesonofthom.tools.TimeFormatter

  • public class TimeFormatter
extends java.lang.Object
    While Java has useful libraries for parsing calendar dates, it does not have good tools for parsing arbitrary timestamps. Java's built in libraries always treat a time as number of ms since the epoch, not as an absolute value. TimeFormatter allows for formatting durations of time, independent of the date.
    Author:
    Kevin Thomson

    • Constructor Detail

      • TimeFormatter

        public TimeFormatter()
        Class to print a specified time duration in human readable form. This constructor gives a "best fit" string, only printing the fields that are necessary to completely describe the time without any loss of precision

      • TimeFormatter

        public TimeFormatter(java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit lowestPossibleTimeUnit,
             java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit highestPossibleTimeUnit,
             boolean forceMinTimeUnit,
             boolean forceMaxTimeUnit)
        Class to print a specified time duration in human readable form. Possible units range from NANOSECONDS to DAYS. User can artificially limit the granularity of the string is by specifying min and max time limits in the constructor
        Parameters:
        lowestPossibleTimeUnit - minimum time unit that will be printed. If the value being printed has a lower granularity than this value, the value will truncated. Min possible: NANOSECONDS
        highestPossibleTimeUnit - maximum time unit that will be printed. Max possible: DAYS
        forceMinTimeUnit - if TRUE, will always print down to the minimum time unit, even if it is 0. if FALSE, will print only down to the last non-0 time unit
        forceMaxTimeUnit - if TRUE, will print up to the maximum time unit, even it if is 0. if FALSE, will only print up to the last non-0 time unit
        See Also:
        TimeUnit

    • Method Detail

      • timeUnitLimit

        public static int timeUnitLimit(java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Parameters:
        timeUnit -
        Returns:
        the maximum range of values that can fit within the specified time limit without spilling over into the next time unit. Also, value to scale by to convert from one time unit to the next (E.G. to convert from SECONDS to MINUTES, multiply by the SECONDS value. To convert from SECONDS to MILLISECONDS, divide by the MILLISECONDS value).

      • timeUnitSuffix

        public static java.lang.String timeUnitSuffix(java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Parameters:
        timeUnit -
        Returns:
        a short-hand string representation of the specified time unit. (EX. NANOSECONDS returns "ns" and MINUTES returns "m")
